z:row.TitlePrimary: Smes Design and use .1.
z:row.Keyword: Materials Science, Multidisciplinary|Physics, Applied|Physics, Condensed Matter
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD, ENGLAND OX5 1GB
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: SHONAN INST TECHNOL,FUJISAWA,JAPAN.; BOOM, RW, UNIV WISCONSIN,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Large and small-scale SMES-design studies are reported here in Part 1 (5000 MWh) and Part 2 (10 MWh) papers by the authors. Designs and efficiency are discussed. Costs for 10 MWh in Japan are about 6x Break-Even value; costs for 5000 MWh in the U. S. and Japan1] are probably at Break-Even value. A new axial rippled, flat pancake SMES coil2], recently introduced at ASC in Chicago, is reviewed and suggested for both large and small SMES.3]

z:row.TitlePrimary: Smes Design and use .2.
z:row.Keyword: Materials Science, Multidisciplinary|Physics, Applied|Physics, Condensed Matter
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD, ENGLAND OX5 1GB
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,MADISON,WI 53706.; MASUDA, M, SHONAN INST TECHNOL,FUJISAWA,JAPAN.
z:row.Abstract: The uses for small storage units by industrial and commercial customers will be given in contrast to Part-1, where large coils are discussed. In one specific application for business building, the economical efficiency of small SMES (<10 MWh) will be discussed. The break even capital cost (BECC) of such unit is derived and compared with the construction cost. It shows a construction cost 3 to 6 times more expensive than the BECC. The storage efficiencies of small SMES are also discussed. The overall efficiency including all losses shows 75% for a 10 MWh unit.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Superconductive Magnetic Energy-Storage (Smes) External Fields and Safety Considerations
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 345 E 47TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10017-2394
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,CTR APPL SUPERCONDUCT,MADISON,WI 53706.; POLK, C, UNIV RHODE ISL,DEPT ELECT ENGN,KINGSTON,RI 02881.
z:row.Abstract: This paper addresses preferred SMES configurations and the external magnetic fields which they generate. Possible biological effects of fields are reviewed briefly. It is proposed that SMES units be fenced at the 10 gauss (1 mT) level to keep unrestricted areas safe, even for persons with cardiac pacemakers. For a full size 5000 MWh (1.8 x 10(13) J) SMES the magnetic field decreases to 10 gauss at a radial distance of 2 km from the center of the coil. Other considerations related to the environmental impact of large SMES magnetic fields are discussed briefly.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Visualization of droplet break-up in pre-mix membrane emulsification using microfluidic devices
z:row.TitleTertiary: Colloids Surf. A, Physicochem. Eng. Aspects (Netherlands)
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Colloids and Surfaces A (Physicochemical and Engineering Aspects)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Food & Bioprocess Eng. Group, Wageningen Univ., Netherlands
z:row.Abstract: To investigate the break-up of emulsion droplets in pre-mix or dead-end membrane emulsification, a microscopic study was conducted in microfluidic devices. Channels with shapes such as constrictions, junctions, and combinations thereof representing ideal membrane structures where etched in silicon. Through these structures pre-mix emulsion droplets where pushed, which was recorded with high-speed video microscopy. Accumulation of droplets of the dispersed phase before and inside the pore network was found to occur under all conditions. Thus, the effective volume fraction of dispersed phase inside the pores is always high. In a brick-shaped pore structure, an optimum thickness of the layer was found. In these structures, channelling occurs below a critical pressure difference over the structure. In the channelling regime, isolated channels are active, effectively excluding action of branchings and junctions. We found three main categories of break-up mechanisms (snap-off due to localized shear, break-up due to interfacial tension effects, and break-up due to steric hindrance) and were able to quantify some. Break-up due to branchings and junctions do not seem to be essential for break-up to occur. It is, however, clear that the other phenomena (accumulation, channelling) can have major impact on the total behaviour of the system and should not be neglected. [All rights reserved Elsevier]
z:row.User2: visualization; emulsion droplet break-up; dead-end membrane emulsification; microfluidic devices; dispersed phase; brick-shaped pore structure; effective volume fraction; interfacial tension

z:row.TitlePrimary: Effects of particle size segregation on crossflow microfiltration performance: Control mechanism for concentration polarisation and particle fractionation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Food & Bioprocess Eng. Group, Wageningen Univ., Netherlands
z:row.Abstract: Although the principal mechanisms of crossflow microfiltration (MF) are well-known, the practical applicability of the resulting microfiltration models is still limited. This can be largely attributed to the lack of understanding of effects of polydispersity in the particulate suspensions, as relevant to concentration polarisation in MF. This paper describes an investigation of concentration polarisation behaviour of bidisperse suspensions, in the regime where shear-induced diffusion is the dominant back-transport mechanism. In the transient flux regime, the particle deposition onto the membrane was monitored by means of confocal scanning laser microscopy. As in accordance with the linear dependence of the shear-induced diffusivity on a2, only the small particles in the bidisperse suspensions were found to deposit onto the membrane. The back-transport flux that was calculated from the deposition rate and the actual permeate flux, was found to be independent of the composition of the suspension, whereas it was equal to the back-transport flux of a monodisperse suspension of the small particles only, with a similar total particle fraction. These results can be explained with the occurrence of particle size segregation in the feed flow, which leads to an enrichment with small particles of the suspension near the membrane. The findings are also shown to be relevant to particle fractionation processes by MF. In such fractionation processes, particle size segregation is found to have a strong effect on the separation characteristics such as particle size and fat content of the permeate. A polydisperse suspension could be fractionated using a membrane having a pore size larger than the largest particles present. The fractionation thus results not from size exclusion in the membrane, but from segregation effects in the feed channel. [All rights reserved Elsevier]
z:row.User2: particle size segregation; crossflow microfiltration; control mechanism; concentration polarisation; particle fractionation; polydispersity; particulate suspension; bidisperse suspension; shear-induced diffusion; back-transport mechanism; transient flux regime; particle deposition; confocal scanning laser microscopy; membrane; permeate flux; feed flow

z:row.TitlePrimary: Lattice Boltzmann simulation of 2D and 3D non-Brownian suspensions in Couette flow
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Food & Bioprocess Eng. Group, Wageningen Univ., Netherlands
z:row.Abstract: In this study, the Lattice Boltzmann (LB) method is applied for computer simulation of suspension flow in Couette systems. Typical aspects of Couette flow such as wall effects and non-zero Reynolds numbers can be studied well with the LB method because of its time-dependent character. Couette flow of single, two and multi-particle systems was studied, where two-dimensional (2D) systems were compared with three-dimensional (3D) systems. Computations on multi-particle 3D suspensions, for instance to assess the viscosity or shear-induced diffusivity, were found to be very intensive. This was only partly a consequence of the 3D system size. The critical particle grid size, necessary for accurate results, was found to be relatively large, increasing the system to impractical sizes. It is however demonstrated that it is possible to carry out computer simulations on 2D suspensions and use relatively simple, linear scaling relations to translate these results to 3D suspensions, in this way avoiding intensive computations. By doing so, the LB method is shown to be well-suited for study of suspension flow in Couette systems, particularly for aspects as particle layering near solid walls, hydrodynamic particle interactions and viscous stresses at non-zero Reynolds numbers, which cannot be easily solved with alternative methods. It also opens the way to employ the LB method for other unexplored aspects, such as particle polydispersity and high Reynolds number flow, with large relevance to practical processing of suspensions. [All rights reserved Elsevier]
z:row.User2: lattice Boltzmann simulation; 2D nonBrownian tensions; 3D nonBrownian tensions; Couette flow; suspension flow; nonzero Reynolds numbers; single particle systems; two particle systems; multiparticle systems; viscosity; shear-induced diffusivity; critical particle grid size; linear scaling relations; solid walls; hydrodynamic particle interactions; viscous stresses; particle polydispersity; high Reynolds number flow

z:row.TitlePrimary: A new pulsed electric field microreactor: comparison between the laboratory and microtechnology scale
z:row.Keyword: biomembranes|cellular biophysics|electric fields|finite element analysis|food preservation|food processing industry|microactuators|microorganisms
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Food & Bioprocess Eng. Group, Wageningen Univ., Netherlands
z:row.Abstract: This paper presents a new microreactor dedicated for pulsed electric field treatment (PEF), which is a pasteurization method that inactivates microorganisms with short electric pulses. The PEF microreactor consists of a flow-through channel with a constriction where the electric field is focused. Compared to a laboratory-scale setup 25 times lower voltages were needed to obtain the same electric field strength due to the close electrode spacing. A finite element model showed that the electric field intensity is very homogeneous throughout the channel, which is crucial for the pasteurization processes. Experiments where artificial vesicles, loaded with carboxyfluorescein, were electroporated showed that the maximum transmembrane potential adequately described the processes both in the microreactor and the laboratory-scale setup, although the length scales are different. Electroporation started at a transmembrane potential of 0.5 V, reaching a maximum fraction of electroporated vesicles of 51% at a transmembrane potential of 1.5 V. The partial electroporation is not a result of the heterogeneity of the vesicles or the electric field. With this new PEF microreactor it is possible to study the PEF process in more detail
z:row.User2: pulsed electric field microreactor; pasteurization; microorganisms; flow-through channel; constriction; electric field strength; finite element model; electric field intensity; artificial vesicles; carboxyfluorescein; transmembrane potential; electroporation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Effect of MgO and Al2O3 variations in oxygen steelmaking (BOF) slag on slag morphology and phosphorus distribution
z:row.Publisher: Institute of Materials, London, SW1Y 5DB, United Kingdom
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Department of Materials and Metallurgical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur 208016, India
z:row.Abstract: Operational data of BOF and the slag samples for different starting conditions of phosphorus (0.06-0.26%P) and silicon content (0.3-1.2%Si) of hot metal have been analysed. The contribution of parameters which are well known to affect phosphorus distribution at tap, such as basicity, temperature, FeO content of slag, slag mass etc., is investigated through models of the ionic theory of slag, optical basicity, regular solution approach, and molecular theory of slag. The best overall results are obtained by the model based on the molecular theory of slag in which several operational parameters are also incorporated. Investigations of different slag samples, based on optical, SEM, EPMA and X-ray studies, reveal the effect of MgO and Al2O3 on slag morphology and phosphorus distribution in different phases. It is important to consider the phosphorus distribution ratio in the solid and liquid part of the slag. The solid part of the slag, which is mostly dicalciumsilicate, can contain up to 5% phosphorus. The phosphorus content of the liquid part of the slag may depend upon the phosphorus content of the hot metal or the phosphorus load of the slag. It is found that incorporation of the effect of dicalciumsilicate in the model improves the accuracy of prediction. For better process control the addition of iron ore towards the end of the blow must be avoided while treating high phosphorus hot metal or during the production of ultralow phosphorus steels. © 2005 Institute of Materials, Minerals and Mining.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: BOF; Phosphorus distribution; Slag morphology; Dicalciumsilicate

z:row.TitlePrimary: Slags and fluxes entering the new millennium, an analysis of recent trends in research and development
z:row.Keyword: Research and development management|Fluxes|Slags|Industrial research|Steelmaking|Recycling|Environmental protection|Environmental impact
z:row.Publisher: Institute of Materials, London, SW1Y 5DB, United Kingdom
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Corus Research, Development and Technology, IJmuiden Technology Centre, 1970 CA IJmuiden, Netherlands
z:row.Abstract: This paper details the recent trends in slag related research from 1999 to 2003. The trends in the following are outlined: Annual publication rate Geographical origin of the work Nature of the research (e.g. thermodynamics, kinetics) Nature of the slag studied. This study has revealed that slag research in the USA and Europe has decreased to about a half over the last 20 years and that there has been a significant decrease in Japanese research in this area in recent years. However, these decreases have been offset by significant increases in Chinese and Korean research activity. There has been a significant increase in the amount of work carried out on recycling and environmental aspects of slags in recent years. © 2005 Institute of Materials, Minerals and Mining.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Literature surveys; Molten slags; Slag splashing; Refractory erosion

z:row.TitlePrimary: Strategies for development of process control models for hot metal desulfurization: Conventional and AI techniques
z:row.Keyword: Metals|Desulfurization|Process control|Artificial intelligence|Technology transfer|Data acquisition|Mathematical models|Fuzzy sets|Genetic algorithms
z:row.Publisher: Taylor and Francis Inc., Philadelphia PA, PA 19106, United States
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Department of Materials and Metallurgical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India
z:row.Abstract: Process control models can be developed by using both conventional and AI approaches. The conventional approaches include regression models and process kinetic models, and the artificial intelligence (AI) approaches are based on artificial neural nets (ANN), genetic algorithm (GA), and fuzzy rule-based expert systems (FRBES). Plant data on hot metal desulfurization, carried out by injecting calcium carbide, is analyzed to test and tune different types and combinations of models and then evaluate their relative performance. Although the control models based on process fundamentals provide a fillip to the new ideas for technological developments and improvements, the combination of conventional and AI approaches may be a better option for process control on the shop floor. It is advisable to first develop and test all models and then decide about the best strategy of using them. Copyright © Taylor and Francis, Inc.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Conventional approach; Desulfurization of hot metals; Process control models

z:row.TitlePrimary: Slag-droplet model: A dynamic tool to simulate and optimise the refining conditions in BOF
z:row.Keyword: Slags|Drop formation|Metal refining|Mathematical models|Computer simulation|Optimization|High temperature operations|Precipitation (chemical)|Reaction kinetics
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: IIT Kanpur, Kanpur, India
z:row.Abstract: Prior knowledge and control of the path of slag evolution during the blow are crucial for the optimal performance of the BOF process. This is, however, not an easy task owing to the complexity of the multicomponent-multiphase reactions at high temperatures and the fact that the on-line data available to simulate the process during the blow are limited. A slag-droplet model was developed in the nineties on the basis of multicomponent mixed transport control theory, the production of iron-oxide through jet-metal interaction and droplet formation, waste gas analysis, dissolution rate of scrap, lime, ore, etc., and slag foaming. Recently, when new blowing practices had to be developed to cope with the changes needed in lining life and converter availability, the slag droplet model was used as a dynamic tool to guide the process adjustments. Operating practices were evaluated for retained slag practice and increased burned dolomite addition. Audiometer signals were recorded during the blow. The results obtained during plant trials, as described in this work, supported the predictions of the model and resulted in improvement of the practice. Precipitation rate of second phase particles (2CaO.SiO2 and 3CaO.SiO2) in slag substantially influences slag foaming behaviour.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Slag droplet model; BOF; Multicomponent multiphase reactions; Dolomite; Slag foaming behavior

z:row.TitlePrimary: Ferronickel production in Kosova - Past performance and new opportunities
z:row.Keyword: Nickel metallurgy|Plant shutdowns|Heavy oil production|Rotary kilns|Sulfur|Energy efficiency|Lignite|Environmental protection
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Lab. for Material Sci. and Technol., Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands
z:row.Abstract: The Feronikeli complex, located in Glogovc of Kosova, consists of open cast mines with estimated reserves of 24 Mt of laterite ferronickel ore with an average Ni+Co content of 1.25 %, and a large metallurgical complex with an installed capacity of 12000 t of nickel in ferronickel per year. It began operating in 1984 and was shut down in 1998 due to the armed conflict in Kosova. The installed technology was state-of-the-art at the time and is described in the paper. Past performance technological problems are analysed and solutions are proposed. The main problems during the Operation were due to the high sulphur contents of both the heavy oil used as a fuel in the rotary kiln as well as of the Kosova basin lignite used as a reductant in the process. The reconstruction of the plant is an ideal opportunity to upgrade the process in terms of energy efficiency and environmental control. Recommendations for revamp to this effect are formulated.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Ferronickel complex

z:row.TitlePrimary: Discrete particle simulations predicting mixing behavior of solid substrate particles in a rotating drum fermenter
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wageningen Centre for Food Sciences, 6700 AN Wageningen, Netherlands
z:row.Abstract: A soft-sphere discrete particle model was used to simulate mixing behavior of solid substrate particles in a slow rotating drum for solid-state fermentation. In this approach, forces acting on and subsequent motion of individual particles can be predicted. The (2D) simulations were qualitatively and quantitatively validated by mixing experiments using video and image analysis techniques. It was found that the simulations successfully predicted the mixing progress as a function of the degree of filling and size of the drum. It is shown that only relatively large, straight baffles perpendicular to the drum wall (67% of the drum radius) increase the mixing performance of the rotating drum. Considering the different aspects of mixing dealt with in this work, it is concluded that the soft sphere discrete particle model can serve as a valuable tool for investigating mixing of solid substrate particles. Finally, it is expected that this model may evolve into a potential tool for design and scale-up of mixed solid-state fermenters. © 2001 John Wiley and Sons, Inc.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Rotating drums

z:row.TitlePrimary: Recycling of scrap for high quality steel products
z:row.Keyword: Steel scrap|Recycling|Dissolution|Metal melting|Zinc alloys|Electrochemistry|Mass transfer|Electrodeposition|Distillation|Vacuum applications|Slags|Caustic soda
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Corus Research, Development/Technol., Netherlands Inst. for Metals Res., Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands
z:row.Abstract: In an ECSC project several aspects of tramp element control in steel were studied by a group of steel producers and research institutes in the European Union. Upgrading of incinerator scrap and shredded automobile and consumer durable scrap was realised through size and density separation and by pre-dismantling and sorting of goods before shredding. Removal of tin from tinplate by pre-treatment with reactive gases was investigated. A dezincing process was developed by dissolution of the zinc-alloy layer in caustic soda followed by electrochemical deposition of zinc. Results of laboratory scale trials showed that generation of high mass transfer between the phases metal-slag-gas as well as vacuum distillation of the solute elements influencing the evaporation rate can remove copper and zinc from steel melts. A mass balance for the distribution of zinc and lead between metal, slag and dust during scrap melting in an EAF was established. Additional sponge iron charging is a very efficient measure to lower zinc and lead content due to the CO boiling effect during melting.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Vacuum distillation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Recent trends in research on slags
z:row.Keyword: Iron and steel industry|Slags|Publishing|Industrial economics|Recycling|Iron and steel plants|Environmental impact|Environmental protection|Industrial research|Steel research
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Corus Research, Development & Technology, Ijmuiden, Neth
z:row.Abstract: The impact of economic slump in South East Asia on the publication of slag related papers is reviewed. It is shown that, if there has been a decrease in slag related publications, it is a small one. More than 30% of slag related publications deal with plant investigations and process modeling and there has been an increase in industrially related studies reported at recent slag conference. There has also been an increase in studies on recycling of slags and their environmental problems.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Slag recycling

z:row.TitlePrimary: Argon solubility in liquid steel
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Metallurgical and Materials Transactions B: Process Metallurgy and Materials Processing Science
z:row.PeriodicalAbbrev: Metall Mat Trans B Process Metall Mat Process Sci
z:row.Publisher: Minerals, Metals and Materials Society, Warrendale, PA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Hoogovens Research & Development, Ijmuiden, Neth
z:row.Abstract: Experiments have been performed to establish the solubility of argon in liquid interstitial-free steel. The solubility appears to be lower than 0.1 at ppb. The results are in line with argon solubilities reported in the literature on liquid iron. Semiempirical theories and calculations based on the atom embedding method reveal high values (gt;370 kJ/mole) of the enthalpy of solution of single argon atoms in steel. Also, argon clustering is investigated. Furthermore, the enthalpy reduction and therefore solubility enhancement by impurities and oxide particles is discussed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Liquid interstitial free steel; Atom embedding methods; Argon clustering

z:row.TitlePrimary: Software quality management
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Systems House England, Woodley, UK
z:row.Abstract: With the recognition that consistent quality of a firm's products will help ensure repeat orders and help build a good reputation, one company's route to acquire NATO Quality Assurance Standards AQAP 1 and 13 is described. The planning of the route, the development of a quality management system and an assessment of the benefits resulting from implementing such a system are detailed
z:row.User2: AQAP 13; software quality; NATO Quality Assurance Standards; AQAP 1; quality management system

z:row.TitlePrimary: HEPMED: a knowledge base for hepatobiliar diseases
z:row.TitleSecondary: 8th International Workshop. Expert Systems and their Applications. Specialized Conference. Artificial Intelligence and Defense, Expert Systems and Maintenance, Expert Systems and Medicine, 30 May-3 June 1988
z:row.TitleTertiary: 8th International Workshop. Expert Systems and their Applications. Specialized Conference. Artificial Intelligence and Defense, Expert Systems and Maintenance, Expert Systems and Medicine
z:row.Keyword: errors|expert systems|knowledge acquisition|medical diagnostic computing|sensitivity analysis
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Avignon, France
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Inst. de Cibernetica, Univ. Politecnica de Cataluna, Barcelona, Spain
z:row.Abstract: The correct expert system behaviour depends greatly on the adequate modelling of the domain knowledge involved therein and thus, in the ability to shape this knowledge in the knowledge base. HEPMED is a knowledge base created as a result of the analysis of three knowledge sources: the bibliographic, the heuristic and 1000 real cases of adult patients. It is used by an expert system to help in the diagnosis of hepatobiliar diseases related to the presence of jaundice. The whole system is currently being used in 2 general hospitals in Mexico City. The associated error rate was 7.22, sensitivity and specificity analysis results were 92.08% and 98.14% respectively. This paper describes the medical knowledge approach and the expertise test results
z:row.User2: domain knowledge modelling; bibliographic sources; heuristic knowledge; sensitivity analysis; knowledge acquisition; HEPMED; knowledge base; hepatobiliar diseases; expert system behaviour; adult patients; diagnosis; jaundice; general hospitals; error rate; specificity analysis; medical knowledge; expertise test results

z:row.TitlePrimary: Benefits of a sublance system in oxygen steelmaking
z:row.Keyword: Steelmaking -- Basic Oxygen Process|Process Control|Ergonomics|Energy Conservation|Furnaces, Metallurgical--Refractory Materials
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: ESTS Hoogovens Groep BV, IJmuiden, Neth
z:row.Abstract: The sublance system developed for oxygen steelmaking allows state of the art steelmaking control which results in appreciable cost savings and good quality control. ESTS Hoogovens in the Netherlands have installed sublance systems at their IJmuiden steelworks and from this have gained operating experience. ESTS have also provided 18 sublance systems for producers in the USA and Europe, the majority of them installed in operating shops without any interference to production during installation.

z:row.PeriodicalFull: Physica B: Physics of Condensed Matter & C: Atomic, Molecular and Plasma Physics, Optics

z:row.Abstract: Continuing the papers on alloys of Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn and Fe we reviw in the present paper, on the basis of the model developed by Miedema and co-workers, experimental and predicted enthalpies of formation of ordered binary intermetallic compounds of Co with arbitrary metal partners. The enthalpy effects are also reviewed for liquid Co alloys. The predicted values agree quite satisfactorily with the available experimental data for binary systems of Co with a transition metal. In the binary systems where Co is alloyed with a non-transition metal larger differences are sometimes observed. Since Co with other transition metals may often form solid solutions the enthalpy of forming solid solutions is dealt with in a concise way distinguishing between magnetic and non-magnetic matrix metals.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Cohesion in metals: transition metal alloys
z:row.Keyword: binding energy|collections of physical data|enthalpy|heat of formation|heat of reaction|liquid alloys|metal theory|phase diagrams|surface energy|surface segregation|transition metal alloys
z:row.Abstract: The first volume of this new series presents a very simple atomistic model for predicting the heats of formation of alloys involving transition elements. Because of the scarcity of experimental thermodynamic data, the authors determined the sign of the heat of formation from the known behaviour of the binary phase diagrams. By assigning only two co-ordinates to each transition element, they found that they could separate all those binary alloys with positive heats of formation from those with negative values. By fixing the magnitude of the heat of formation to known experimental values, they were able to predict values for all those binary systems which had not yet been measured. This work provided a basis for future development and gave materials scientists an internally-consistent empirical model for assessing energy effects in binary, ternary and quaternary alloys
z:row.User2: solid alloys; cohesion; liquid alloys; transition metal alloys; ternary alloys; surface segregation; binary alloys; atomistic model; heats of formation; binary phase diagrams; empirical model; energy effects; quaternary alloys

z:row.Abstract: We review on the basis of the model developed by Miedema and co-workers, enthalpies of formation of ordered binary intermetallic compounds of Ni with arbitrary metal partners. The enthalpy effects are also examined for liquid Ni alloys. The calculated values agree with the available experimental data for binary systems of Ni with a transition metal, except where Ni is the minority partner in alloys with the more electropositive metals like Y, La and Ti, in which case the model tends to overestimate the enthalpy effects. A formalism is suggested to improve the predictions in these cases. In the binary systems where Ni is alloyed with a non-transition metal differences are sometimes observed between predicted and experimentally determined enthalpies. These discrepancies are analyzed taking into consideration information on all 3d metals.

z:row.Abstract: Early laboratory studies of steel/slag equilibria and laboratory scale experiments to determine lime dissolution rates are described. An outline of a major improvement program for the operation in BOF Shop No. 2 is presented. A comparison is given of different lime addition schemes, e. g. batch or constant rate. Translation of slag formation experience into demands for lime properties is described. Chemical composition of the burnt lime is determined by the source of the raw limestone and the calcination process. Determination of the minimum size of lumps of lime is done by scaling of the converter feeding/waste gas exhaust system. Lime lump granulometry is fixed between 7 and 45 mm. A study of weathering of lime is presented which leads to clear conclusions about transport and storage of burnt lime.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Predicting heat effects in alloys

z:row.Abstract: The authors have previously demonstrated (A.R. Miedema et al., 1975-80) that the enthalpy of alloy formation can be described in terms of a cellular atomic model. Energy effects are expressed as contact interactions that take place at the interface shared by pieces of dissimilar metals having the size of atoms. The consequences of the contact interaction approach are discussed at some length. Examples are: (i) the regular solution approach for the heat of mixing of liquid alloys and the pair interaction model for treating ordering in metallic solid solutions are basically inadequate if the two types of atoms differ appreciably in size; and (ii) an important quantity is fBA, the degree to which A atoms are surrounded by B-type neighbours. This quantity determines the concentration dependence of the formation enthalpies of ordered phases in a binary system and makes it possible to rationalize their occurrence
z:row.User2: heat effects; enthalpy; alloy formation; cellular atomic model; contact interaction; heat of mixing; liquid alloys; ordered phases; interface effects

z:row.Abstract: The diagnosis of common gastroenterological problems (jaundice, acute abdominal pain and upper GI bleeding) by a group of 12 specialists in internal medicine from a 1000 bed general hospital in Mexico City is compared with those provided by a computer working with a bayesian model, from January 1977 to March 1979 (27 months). z:row.Abstract: The introduction of Celox probes for measurement of oxygen activity in the ladle has allowed Hoogovens to improve production of semi-killed steels. On steels containing Si, the probability of internal defects in slabs has been reduced and on qualities with no Si surface conditioning has been cut by 80%.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Surface tension and electron density of pure liquid metals
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Philips Res. Labs., Eindhoven, Netherlands
z:row.Abstract: The authors propose that the basic parameter behind the empirical relation between surface tension and heat of vaporization per unit atomic surface is the electron density at the boundary of pure metal atomic cells, nws. Both the surface energy and the heat of vaporization are linearly related to nws. By taking into account the unusually high stabilities of the free atom configurations of metallic elements like Hg, Cd, Zn and Mg (160, 145, 145 and 125 kJ/mol) exceptions to the above empirical relation are explained
z:row.User2: electron density; pure liquid metals; surface tension; heat of vaporization; free atom configurations; Hg; Cd; Zn; Mg

z:row.TitlePrimary: MODEL PREDICTIONS FOR THE ENTHALPY OF FORMATION OF TRANSITION METAL ALLOYS
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Calphad: Computer Coupling of Phase Diagrams and Thermochemistry
z:row.Abstract: In a series of papers the authors have demonstrated that the heat of formation of binary intermetallic compounds that contain at least one transition metal and that of liquid alloys in general can be described in terms of a simple atomic model. An alloy is suggested that is constructed from Wigner-Seitz atomic cells taken from the pure metallic elements. The alloying energy then originates from a change in boundary conditions when dissimilar atoms get into contact. A model is described and a summary is given of results thus far obtained by means of it. A number of examples are given which demonstrate the usefulness of predictions of enthalpies of formation in the range where experimental information is either lacking or very difficult to obtain.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.Abstract: The authors have previously demonstrated that the heat of formation of binary intermetallic compounds that contain at least one transition metal and that of liquid alloys in general can be described in terms of a simple atomic model. (see, e.g., J. Less Common Met., vol.41, p.283 (1975), vol.46, p.67 (1976); vol.45, p.237 (1976), and vol.46, p.271 (1976)). An alloy is suggested to be constructed from Wigner-Seitz atomic cells taken from the pure metallic elements. The authors describe the model and summarize the results thus far obtained by means of it. The relation to descriptions of interfacial energies between metals is indicated. z:row.Abstract: Energy effects in alloys of transition metals are predominantly nearest-neighbor effects whereas both crystal structure and entropy effects are relatively unimportant. The model description predicts the sign of DELTA H (is the interaction repulsive or attractive? ) for binary systems with 99% accuracy. Progress is made towards the prediction of numerical values for both heats of formation of solid compounds and heats of mixing of liquid alloys.

z:row.Keyword: LIQUID METALS|HEAT TRANSFER - Liquid Metals|METALS AND ALLOYS - Thermodynamic Properties
z:row.Abstract: A quantitative analysis of heats of mixing and solution is given for liquid alloys; all parameters used in the calculations are tabulated. The values calculated from the model generally agree with available experimental data. Discrepancies between model and experiment mainly occur for systems with large negative heats of mixing and can be attributed to ordering effects in the liquid alloy. A complete list of calculated values of heats of solution of metals in liquid iron, uranium, and tin is presented. A comparison is made between the present model and existing models.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: ON THE HEAT OF MIXING OF LIQUID ALLOYS EM DASH 1
z:row.Abstract: It is demonstrated that a simple formula can be applied to the heat of mixing, DELTA H(mix), of liquid alloys of two transition metals as well as of two nontransition metals. The pure metal parameters of the formula are the same as for solid metals; moreover, the values for the proportionality constants P and Q//o are practically unchanged. For alloys of transition (d-type) metals and polyvalent nontransition (p-type) metals, a negative constant, minus R, is to be added for liquid alloys as well as for solid alloys, the value for liquids being about 25% smaller than for solid alloys.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: ON THE HEAT OF FORMATION OF SOLID ALLOYS
z:row.Keyword: METALS AND ALLOYS|CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Reaction Kinetics|THERMODYNAMICS
z:row.Abstract: It is demonstrated that energy effects in alloys of transition metals can be desccribed in terms of the interactions between individual atoms. There are three contributions to the alloying enthalpy, the first representing the difference in electronegativity, the second reflecting the difference in density of electrons at the boundary between dissimilar atoms, and the third term representing an additional hybridisation energy that occurs if transition metals are alloyed with polyvalent nontransition metals.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.Abstract: An alloy is suggested to be constructed from Wigner-Seitz atomic cells taken from the pure metallic elements. The alloying energy then originates from a change in boundary conditions when dissimilar atoms get into contact. There are two terms in the heat of formation. ΔH, a negative one arising from removing the difference in chemical potential between the two types of atomic cells and a positive term that reflects the original discontinuity in the density of electrons at the boundary between dissimilar atomic cells. The model accounts for the heat of mixing of liquid metals as well as for the heats of formation of binary intermetallic compounds with one or two transition metals. The results are formulated in terms of simple rules for alloy formation. It is furthermore demonstrated that the description (and hence the predictions) of ΔH for alloys of transition metals is sufficiently accurate to be of practical interest
z:row.User2: heat of formation; heat of mixing; liquid metals; simple rules for alloy formation; atomic model

z:row.TitlePrimary: Heat of solution of metals in liquid tin
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Amsterdam, Netherlands
z:row.Abstract: In this work experimental data on heats of solution of metals in liquid tin are presented. These data have been used to extend the model description of the binary alloying behaviour of solid metals to binary liquid systems and to make this model quantitative
z:row.User2: liquid Sn; heat of solution; metals; model description; binary alloying behaviour; binary liquid systems

z:row.TitlePrimary: HEAT OF SOLUTION OF METALS IN LIQUID TIN
z:row.Abstract: Presents experimental data on heats of solution of metals in liquid tin. These data have been used to extend the model description of the binary alloying behavior of solid metals as introduced by Miedema et al. to binary liquid systems and to make this model quantitative. Survey collected all published values for heats of solution at infinite dilution of metals in liquid tin. Selected values for the heats of solution are given.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES OF COMPOUNDS IN THE INDIUM-BISMUTH SYSTEM
z:row.Keyword: INDIUM COMPOUNDS|INDIUM BISMUTH ALLOYS - Thermodynamics|SEMICONDUCTING INDIUM COMPOUNDS
z:row.Abstract: Heats of formation at 273 degree K of the compounds InBi, In//5Bi//3 and In//2Bi have been determined to be minus 711 plus or minus 60 cal/g-atom, minus 405 plus or minus 54 cal/g-atom and minus 109 plus or minus 55 cal/g-atom, respectively, by means of liquid tin solution calorimetry. Comparison with earlier measurements and evaluations is made and some conclusions about the relative stability of the compounds are formulated. Heats os solution at infinite dilution of indium, bismuth and silver in tin at 587 degree K are presented.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Possible explanations for the low temperature resistivities of Ni3Al and Ni3Ga alloys in terms of spin density fluctuation theories
z:row.Keyword: aluminium alloys|band model of magnetism|electrical conductivity of solids|gallium alloys|nickel alloys
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Amsterdam, Netherlands
z:row.Abstract: The unusual, strong temperature dependence of the low temperature electrical resistivities of the Ni3Al and Ni3Ga intermetallic phases are analysed in terms of existing theories of scattering of conduction electrons by spin-density fluctuations. A qualitative agreement between theory and experiment is found but none of the theories can adequately describe the detailed behaviour of the resistivities as a function of temperature and bulk susceptibility
z:row.User2: low temperature resistivities; Ni3Al; Ni3Ga; spin density fluctuation; temperature dependence; electrical resistivities; scattering; conduction electrons; bulk susceptibility

z:row.TitlePrimary: Thermodynamic properties of compounds in the indium-bismuth system
z:row.Keyword: heat of formation|heat of solution|indium compounds
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Amsterdam, Netherlands
z:row.Abstract: Heats of formation at 273°K of the compounds InBi, In5Bi3 and In2Bi have been determined to be -711±60 cal/g-atom, -405±54 cal/g-atom and -109±55 cal/g-atom, respectively, by means of liquid tin solution calorimetry. Comparison with earlier measurements and evaluations is made and some conclusions about the relative stability of the compounds are formulated. Heats of solution at infinite dilution of indium, bismuth and silver in tin at 587°K are presented (-124±21 cal/g-atom, 130±47 cal/g-atom and 3637±24 cal/g-atom, respectively)

z:row.TitlePrimary: Scattering of conduction electrons by paramagnons in Ni3Al
z:row.Keyword: aluminium alloys|crystal electron states|electrical conductivity of solids|nickel alloys|paramagnetic properties of substances
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Natuurkundig Lab., Univ. Amsterdam, Netherlands
z:row.Abstract: Reports low temperature electrical resistivity data of the Ni3Al phase. The results are described in terms of scattering of conduction electrons by d-band spin density fluctuations (paramagnons)
